title: R41839
content: The Dodd-Frank Act established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) within the Federal Reserve System to oversee various consumer financial products and services. The CFPB has regulatory, supervisory, and enforcement authority over institutions offering deposit taking, mortgage lending, credit card lending, and other financial services. It also enforces federal consumer laws like the Truth in Lending Act and the Real Estate Settlement Act. The CFPB has the authority to implement federal consumer laws like TILA and RESPA. Some of its powers took effect when Dodd-Frank was signed in 2010, with the rest becoming effective on the designated transfer date. The Bureau is headed by a single Director appointed by the President with Senate approval. The CFP Act grants the Bureau powers, which are affected by the appointment of a Director. The Bureau is to be headed by a Director nominated by the President. Until a Director is appointed, the Secretary has limited authority under Section 1066 of the CFP Act to perform the Bureau's functions. The Treasury Department can provide administrative services to support the Bureau before the designated transfer date. The CFP Act grants the Secretary interim powers to perform the functions of the Bureau until a Director is confirmed. The Treasury Department can provide administrative services to support the Bureau before the designated transfer date. The Secretary's interim authorities, derived from CFP Act subsection 1066(a), allow him to perform limited functions of the Bureau until a Director is confirmed by the Senate. These authorities do not expire until a Director is appointed, unlike administrative powers that expire on the transfer date. Most of the CFPB's authorities, including those under subtitle F, do not go into effect until the transfer date. The Secretary, while exercising Bureau powers within his interim authority, will be subject to the CFP Act's general provisions. The Dodd-Frank Act established the CFPB, with most of its authorities, including those under subtitle F, becoming effective on the designated transfer date. Subtitle F transfers consumer financial protection functions from seven agencies to the Bureau, including rulemaking authority and supervisory powers. The Dodd-Frank Act established the CFPB with rulemaking and supervisory powers transferred from seven agencies to the Bureau. This includes authority to issue guidelines, conduct studies, and transfer personnel as necessary. The CFPB was established under the Dodd-Frank Act with rulemaking and supervisory powers transferred from seven agencies. Personnel transfers to the CFPB must occur within 90 days of the designated transfer date. The Secretary can exercise the Bureau's authorities until a Director is appointed, including consumer compliance supervisory powers and rule issuance. Administrative support functions are also provided until the transfer date. The powers under subtitle F are expansive but do not cover all of the CFPB's powers. The CFPB, established under the Dodd-Frank Act, has rulemaking and supervisory powers transferred from seven agencies. The Bureau's newly established powers include enhanced supervisory powers over non-depository financial institutions, new rulemaking powers, and limited enforcement powers over smaller depository institutions. These powers are provided under subtitle F and section 1024 of the CFP Act. The CFPB, established under the Dodd-Frank Act, has rulemaking and supervisory powers transferred from seven agencies. The Bureau's newly established powers under section 1024 of the CFP Act include supervising non-depository financial institutions such as providers of payday loans, mortgage loans, and student loans. The Bureau has the authority to conduct examinations, impose reporting requirements, and identify "larger participants" in consumer financial markets for supervision. The CFPB's powers under section 1024 of the CFP Act allow it to supervise non-depository financial institutions and enforce consumer compliance. These powers include requiring registration, setting eligibility standards, and conducting examinations to detect risks to consumers. The Bureau can also issue regulations, orders, and guidance as necessary for enforcement. The CFPB's rulemaking powers under the CFP Act allow it to prescribe regulations, issue orders, and provide guidance to administer consumer financial laws. Subtitle C grants specific authority for regulations, including declaring acts as unfair, deceptive, or abusive. The Bureau can also require disclosures and establish model forms. Enforcement and supervisory powers over smaller depository institutions are included. The general rulemaking provisions of subtitle B are in effect, while specific rulemaking authorities under subtitle C will take effect on the designated transfer date. The CFPB's enforcement and supervisory powers over smaller depository institutions are limited, with the Bureau playing a back-up role to banking regulators. The CFP Act does not give the Bureau primary enforcement power over these institutions but allows for referral of potential enforcement actions to banking regulators. The Bureau may participate in examinations of smaller depository institutions and access examination reports prepared by banking regulators. The CFPB can require smaller depository institutions to create and submit reports directly to the Bureau. The CFPB has limited supervisory and enforcement authority over smaller depository institutions, with the authority to require them to submit reports directly. These powers are separate from administrative services and will likely be exercised once a Bureau Director is appointed. The actions taken by the Bureau so far have been mainly administrative or in preparation for substantive authorities to take effect on the designated transfer date. The Bureau has mainly taken administrative and preparatory actions, such as talking to interested parties, collecting information, coordinating personnel transfer, and hiring new staff. These steps align with its responsibilities outlined in the Treasury Department's 2010 annual report. The Bureau has been taking administrative and preparatory actions such as hiring new personnel, securing office space, and websites. These actions align with the Treasury Department's 2010 annual report and the Bureau's planned activities outlined in the Federal Register notice. The majority of the Bureau's transferred powers will go into effect on the designated transfer date, including consumer compliance supervisory and enforcement powers over larger depository institutions and rulemaking authority under various consumer laws. After the designated transfer date, the Bureau will acquire consumer compliance supervisory and enforcement powers over larger depository institutions, as well as rulemaking authority under TILA, RESPA, and other consumer laws. The potential expansion of interim powers without a Bureau Director could lead to substantive actions impacting financial institutions in consumer markets. For example, the FRB proposed regulations under TILA to impose origination standards on certain mortgage lenders. The 474-page proposal was issued on April 19, 2011, open for comments until July 22, 2011—one day after the transfer date. On July 21, 2011, the authority to prescribe regulations under TILA will transfer to the Bureau. After the transfer date, the Bureau will acquire supervisory and enforcement powers over depository institutions, along with rulemaking authority under TILA and other consumer laws. Final regulations imposing mortgage origination standards must be prescribed by the Bureau, not the FRB. The Secretary may also have authority to issue these regulations until a Bureau Director is appointed. The limits of the Secretary's authorities under the CFP Act may not always be clear, leading to potential lawsuits from parties claiming negative impacts on their business interests. Parties may initiate lawsuits claiming actions under the CFP Act exceed the Secretary's authority, with unpredictable outcomes due to various circumstances.
